A limit order is an order to buy or sell at a specific price or better. Limit orders are not guaranteed to execute.
Market order is immediately matched to the best available market price.

OCO Order: To place a Stop-Limit order (the Trigger Stop Price should be higher than Market Price for Buy order, and lower for Sell order), and a Limit Order (the Limit Price should be lower than Market Price for Buy order, and higher for Sell order) at the same time. When either of the order pairs is triggered, the other order will be canceled. And if either of the order pairs is canceled, the other order will be canceled too.
A Stop-Limit order is an order to buy or sell a coin once the price reaches a specified price.
Account Equity = Total balance - Total Debt

Fiat P2P trading is also known as peer to peer (P2P) trading. In a P2P trade, users deal directly with his/her counterparty, exchanging the Fiat asset offline and confirming the transaction online. Once the offline Fiat asset exchange is confirmed by both parties, the digital asset is released to the buyer.\10 A P2P platform serves as the facilitator of the trade by providing a platform for buyers and sellers to broadcast their offers. At the same time, the escrow services of online digital assets ensures the safety and timely delivery of digital assets during trade execution.

Binance P2P serves as a marketplace where users can buy and sell cryptocurrencies from and to each other using Fiat currencies. Binance P2P aims to provide easy access to cryptocurrencies and advance the vision of “Freedom of Money”.

1. Register and complete your KYC. 2. Add payment method: Click on Account > P2P Settings > Payment Method > Add new payment method > Activate 3. Buy Crypto: Click on Trades > Select P2P tab > Select Buy tab > Enter quantity you would like to purchase > Click on Buy BTC > Confirm trade details > Select a payment method > Transfer Cash offline according to the instructions in transaction details > Click on \"Paid” button > Wait for seller’s confirmation > The transaction is completed and crypto will be released to the buyer’s account.

1. Transfer funds to P2P Wallet: Click Funds > Click Fiat > Select exchange from Exchange wallet to P2P wallet > Enter amount you would like to transfer > Click Transfer. 2. Sell your crypto: Click on Trades > Select Sell tab > Enter quantity you would like to sell > Click on Sell BTC > Confirm trade details > Select a payment method > Wait for the buyer to transfer money offline > Click on ”Release Crypto” button after confirming the offline payment > the transaction is completed and crypto will be released to the buyer’s account.
There is no limit on the amount you can buy or sell imposed by the platform. Users can freely choose the merchant they would like to trade with. Each advertisement has different purchase limits.

Usually, users can withdraw their funds immediately after a purchase. However, if the risk management system is triggered, a T+1 withdrawal restriction will be imposed on funds purchased via P2P.

What are Cross and Isolated modes?

Cross Margin Mode: All cross positions under the same margin asset share the same asset cross margin balance. In the event of liquidation, your assets full margin balance along with any remaining open positions under the asset may be forfeited. \10\10 Isolated Margin Mode: Margin assigned to a position is restricted to a certain amount. If the margin falls below the Maintenance Margin level, the position is liquidated. However, you can add and remove margin at will under this method.

1. Your staked ETH must be locked during the first phase of ETH 2.0 upgrade. During this lock-up period, your staked ETH cannot be redeemed. Please carefully consider the involved risks.
2. You will be able to redeem your staked ETH when the first phase of ETH 2.0 completes, which could take up to 24 months.
3. BETH is a tokenized asset representing your staked ETH on a 1:1 basis. Binance distributes the BETH to your spot account.
4. You can swap your BETH back to ETH after the completion of the first phase. Please note, that you will receive ETH equal to your BETH holdings at the time of the swap.

Activation Price is one of the trigger conditions for Trailing Stop order. If no activation price is set, the activation price will be the market price by default (either \"Last Price\" or \"Mark Price\"). When the highest/lowest market price reaches or exceeds the Activation Price after the Trailing Stop order is submitted, the condition is considered to be satisfied.

Callback Rate is one of the trigger conditions for Trailing Stop order. After the Activation Price is satisfied, if the rebound rate of the highest/lowest market price is greater than or equal to the Callback Rate, the Trailing Stop Order will be executed. The callback rate ranges from 0.1% to 5%.

The proportion of net long and net short accounts to total accounts of the top 20% users with the highest margin balance. Each account is counted once only.\10Long Account % = Accounts of top traders with net long positions / Total accounts of top traders with open positions\10Short Account % = Accounts of top traders with net short positions / Total accounts of top traders with open positions\10Long/Short Ratio (Accounts) = Long Account % / Short Account %
The difference between the futures price and the price index at a given time.\10Basis = Futures Price - Price Index\10Basis Rate = ( Futures Price - Price Index ) / Price Index

The proportion of net long and net short positions to total open positions of the top 20% users with the highest margin balance.\10Long Position % = Long positions of top traders / Total open positions of top traders\10Short Position % = Short positions of top traders / Total open positions of top traders\10Long/Short Ratio (Positions) = Long Position % / Short Position %
Taker Buy Volume: the total volume of buy orders filled by takers within the period.\10Taker Sell Volume: the total volume of sell orders filled by takers within the period.

The proportion of net long and net short accounts to total accounts with positions. Each account is counted once only.\10Long Account % = Accounts with net long positions / Total Accounts with positions\10Short Account % = Accounts with net short positions / Total Accounts with positions\10Long/Short Ratio = Long Account % / Short Account %

PNL is the estimated profit and loss for closing the position. The commission fee and the actual trading price will cause a large difference between the estimated value and the actual value. These values are only for reference. The estimated PNL of the closing position with market order is calculated based on the real-time best buying and selling price. The estimated PNL of the closing position with limit order is calculated based on the limit price entered.

At the end of the interest-free period, loans with lower interest rates receive interest-free priority until the quota is reached. Loans that exceed the interest-free limit accrue interest at 00:00 UTC+0 daily.

At the end of the interest-free period, the principal with low interest rate is given priority to enjoy an interest rate reduction. The principal that has used the Interest Free Borrow Limit will not accrue interest at 00:00 (UTC+0) daily.
The principal of the loan without the Interest Free Limit will accrue at 00:00 (UTC+0) daily.

Use Cross Collateral to trade Futures

Cross Collateral is a model that uses held Crypto assets as collateral and borrows USDT as margin to participate in Futures trading. Cross Collateral lets you participate in Futures trading without needing to sell the coins you currently hold.

Cross Margin uses all the Margin balance in your Futures account to avoid liquidation. In the event of liquidation, the trader might lose all the Margin balance and open positions. Please manage your position carefully to limit the risk due to an unforeseen market event.

PNL is the estimated profit and loss for closing the position. The commission fee and the actual trading price will cause a large difference between the estimated value and the actual value. These values are only for reference. The estimated PNL of the closing position with stop market order is calculated based on the trigger price. The estimated PNL of the closing position with limit stop order is calculated based on the limit price entered.
A positive gap means that price increases will lead to liquidation. A negative gap means that a price drop will lead to a liquidation.

Estimated liquidation price is only a predicted value when a position is first initiated. The actual liquidation price will depend on the trading price, open orders and commission fees, which may vary from the estimated liquidation price. Please note that this calculation is for reference only.
A calculation of Mark Price is base on the index price. Index Price is an aggregate price extracted from the major spot exchanges, weighted by their relative volume.

Trailing Stop orders allow traders to send a pre-set order to the market when a market swing takes place. When the latest Market Price/Mark Price reaches the highest/lowest price (1 ± Callback Rate) after an order is submitted, this triggers the order to be executed on the market and the Trigger Price will be the highest/lowest price* (1 ± Callback Rate).

One-Triggers-a One Cancels the-Other order (OTOCO) allows you to place two orders - a primary order and two secondary orders at the same time.

BSC Zone is a group of tradable protocol tokens built on the Binance Smart Chain.
DeFi Zone is a dedicated trading zone where users are able to trade decentralized finance (DEFI) protocol tokens.
Index zone is a group of tradable crypto indexes allows users to trade broad based sectors and baskets of token projects in a single index.

Innovation Zone is a dedicated trading zone where users are able to trade new, innovative tokens that are likely to have higher volatility and pose a higher risk than other tokens. Risk warning: Trading pairs listed in Innovation Zone poses higher than normal risk, and as such will likely be subject to high price volatility. Please ensure that you exercise sufficient risk management, that you have done your own research in regards to project’s fundamentals and fully understand the project before opting to trade.
NFT Zone is a group of tradable non-fungible token projects.

BNB is a token issued by Binance, with a constant total supply of 200 million. It can be used to enjoy discounts and fee deductions.

BTC is the representative currency of digital assets and the most famous digital currency. The biggest difference between it and other digital currencies is that the total quantity is very limited and it is extremely scarce.

BUSD is a stable currency that is anchored 1:1 with the US Dollar based on blockchain technology. It uses an independent third-party accounting firm to audit assets that can be used as a hedge currency.
USDT is a digital currency pegged to the US Dollar. The exchange ratio is 1:1 and it is used as a currency to replact the US Dollar in cryptocurrency exchanges.

Binance Leveraged Tokens Risk Disclosure Statement\10\10 Please read this risk disclosure statement carefully. Binance describes the general and specific risks associated with Leveraged Tokens (“Leveraged Tokens”) as part of Binance’s products and services you may enter into from time to time. This statement is not meant to be an exhaustive list. You must read this statement in accordance with Binance Terms of Use found at https://www.binance.com/en/terms. Binance offers Leveraged Tokens as products and services to you on the basis that you understand the risks involved. \10\10 You should always carefully consider whether Binance Leveraged Tokens are consistent with your risk tolerance, investment objectives, investment experience or sophistication, financial condition, financial needs and personal circumstances, and other considerations that may be relevant to you.\10\10 You should keep yourself informed and be aware of investment risks generally, and in particular, the following:\10\10 Binance Leveraged Tokens are an investment with risk.\10\10 Investing/trading in Leveraged Tokens is a risky endeavour. Although Binance Leveraged Tokens generally have lower risks and costs compared to derivatives and conventional leveraged tokens (managed by other than Binance), they are not a risk-free investment. As a trader, you acknowledge and agree that you shall access and use Binance Leveraged Tokens at your own risk. You should fully understand the risks associated with Binance Leveraged Tokens and be solely responsible and liable for any and all trading and non-trading activity on your Binance account. Do not enter into a transaction or invest using funds that are beyond your financial means.\10\10 Binance Leveraged Tokens are not a long term investment.\10\10 Investors or traders with longer-term investment horizons shall purchase and hold the Binance Leveraged Tokens at their own risk. There is a possibility that the value of Binance Leveraged Tokens can become zero (0) and cannot be recovered due to inherent market risks, high fees, slippage, rebalance algorithm frontrunning and any other perceived unknown risks associated with Binance Leveraged Tokens.\10\10 Binance Leveraged Tokens rebalance on an as-needed basis only.\10\10 Binance Leveraged Tokens are designed to be unpredictable in rebalance to reduce the vulnerability of being attacked by algorithms on market. Unlike conventional leveraged tokens (not managed by Binance), Binance Leveraged Tokens do not maintain a constant leverage ratio. Hence, Binance Leveraged Tokens only rebalance during extreme market movements. The rebalancing of positions of Binance Leveraged Tokens is governed by Binance’s proprietary algorithms with the aim to maximize correlation between Binance Leveraged Tokens and the underlying margin-leverage position without a profit-guarantee.\10\10 Commissions, fees and charges associated with Binance Leveraged Tokens.\10\10 Before you invest or trade Binance Leveraged Tokens, you should obtain a clear explanation of all commissions, fees and other charges for which you will be liable. These fees will affect your expected returns.\10\10 i. Trading Fees: Trading fees are charged when buying or selling tokens in the Spot market, and the fee schedule is identical to Spot trading as further described in Section 7(c) of the Binance Terms of Use; \10\10 ii. Redemption Fees: Redemption fees are charged when users choose to redeem tokens, which is currently set at 0.1% per redemption; \10\10 iii. Management Fees: A daily management fee of 0.01% will be charged at 00:00 UTC and reflected directly in the net asset value of the Leveraged Tokens; \10\10 iv. Funding Fees: Funding fees are paid (or paid to) the underlying fund based on the funding rate and reflected directly in the net asset value of the Leveraged Tokens. Binance takes no fees for funding rate transfers; these are directly between traders.\10\10 Binance reserves the right to modify or change the fees mentioned above at any time and at its sole discretion. Any such updated fees will apply prospectively to any trades or other transactions that take place following the effective date of such updated fees. You authorize Binance to remove any amounts from your account for any applicable fees owed by you under these Terms.\10\10 Liquidity and pricing risks associated with Binance Leveraged Tokens.\10\10 Due to the nature of Binance Leveraged Tokens’ centralized creation and market liquidity, Binance strives to provide adequate market liquidity and to make Binance Leveraged Tokens available at a fair price. Binance shall take reasonable steps, including, but not limited to, capital injection, additional tokens creation, and selling tokens in the secondary market to minimize the risks mentioned above. The daily total redemption limit of each Leveraged Token is capped at 100,000 tokens. Users may redeem each leveraged token up to the daily cap of 1,000 tokens per account, although this will generally be more expensive than selling them on the Spot market, and is not recommended during normal trading times.

When the Current Price (A) drops to the order’s Limit Price (C) or below, the order will execute automatically. The order will be filled immediately if the buying price is above or equal to the current price. Therefore, the buying price of limit orders must be below the current price.\10\10For example:\101) The current price in the above graph is 2400 (A). If a new buy/limit order is placed with Limit price 1500 (C), the order will not execute until the price drops to %@.\10\102) Instead, if the buy/limit order is placed with Limit price %@, which is above the current price, the order will be filled with the rival price immediately. And the executed price is around 2400, not 3000.\10
A Limit order is to buy or sell at a specific price or better. Limit orders are not guaranteed to execute.

When the Current Price (A) increases to the order’s Limit Price (B) or above, the order will execute automatically. The order might be filled immediately if the selling price is below or equal to the current price. Therefore, the selling price of limit orders must be above the current price.\10\10For example:\101) The current price in the above graph is 2400 (A), if a new sell/limit order is placed with Limit Price 3000 (B), the order will not execute until the price increases to %@.\10\102) Instead, if the sell/limit order is placed with Limit Price %@, which is below the current price, the order would be filled with the rival price immediately; the filled price is around 2400, not 1500.
Market order is immediately matched to the best available market price.

The current price is 2400. If you place a market order, your order will be filled with %@ immediately, it means the average filled price won’t be equal to 2400(A), which is supposed to be a bit lower or higher than 2400.\10\10Note:\101) For buy orders, the average filled price might be a bit higher than current price. And for sell orders, the average filled price might be a bit lower than current price.\10\102) When placing a market order, you can either select [Amount] or [Total] to buy or sell.\10

The Stop Price(B) should be higher than current price for buy orders, and the Limit Price(C) is supposed to be lower than current price.\10\10Note:\101) The Stop Limit order is supposed be triggered when price goes up to %@, and the Limit order will be canceled at the same time. %@\10\102) On the contrary, if the price drops down to %@, the Limit order would execute automatically, and the Stop Limit order is supposed to be canceled. %@

An OCO order contains a limit order and a stop limit order. When either of the orders is triggered, the other order will be canceled. And if either of the orders is canceled, the other order will be canceled as well.

The Stop Price(C) should be lower than current price for sell orders, and the Limit Price(B) is supposed to be higher than current price.\10\10Note:\101) The Stop Limit order is supposed be triggered when price drops down to %@, and the Limit order will be canceled at the same time. %@\10\102) On the contrary, if the price goes up to %@, the Limit order would execute automatically, and the Stop Limit order is supposed to be canceled. %@
A stop-limit order is a order that has both a stop price and a limit price. When the stop price is reached, it triggers the limit order.

The current price is 2400 (A). The stop price of the stop limit order can be above the current price such as 3000 (B), or below the current price such as 1500 (C). Once the price goes up to 3000 (B) or drops down to 1500 (C), the stop limit order triggers, and the limit order will be activated automatically.\10\10Note:\101) Limit price can be above or below stop price for both buy and sell orders. For example, %@ is able to combine with a lower %@, or a higher %@.\10\102) Limit order is invalid before the stop price is triggered, including when the limit price is reached ahead of the stop price.\10\103) When the stop price is reached, it only indicates that a limit order is activated and will be submitted to the market, rather than the limit order being filled immediately. The limit order will execute with its own rules. %@
